Vaccines fully funded by the government   https://web.archive.org/web/20220214093208/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228014111/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-assessing-and-approving-vaccines/covid-19-purchasing-vaccines

Mandatory vaccinations for workers  These sectors and business types are where COVID-19 vaccinations are mandatory.  Border and managed isolation and quarantine workers  Education sector   Health and disability sector  Prison workers  NZ Police  NZ Defence Force  Fire and Emergency New Zealand  Workers covered by the My Vaccine Pass mandate. This applies to food and drink services (excluding businesses that operate solely as takeaways), events, close-proximity businesses and indoor exercise facilities like gyms. The mandate also applies to workers on-site at tertiary education premises when Red settings are in place.  https://archive.fo/8TUmR  https://web.archive.org/web/20220227122622/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-response-planning/covid-19-mandatory-vaccinations
All schools reopened on Jan 31 after Dec break. There is no news of any school closures or restrictions.

All schools reopened on Jan 31 after Dec break. All schools, educational institutions, markets, and shopping centers are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312153847/https://edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/png-education-minister-commends-teachers-for-successful-completion-of-national-examinations  https://web.archive.org/web/20220312154156/https://edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/over-58000-teachers-resume-duties-today  https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

An official national curfew not currently in place, but business operations may be limited to prescribed hours. Officials allow restaurants and gambling establishments to operate under strict health requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221200426/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The following Measures apply to all Provinces:  a. Venues or parts of venues that operate as a restaurant or for food consumption on-premises may operate subject to:  1. all persons on entry and exit from venues must wash their hands with soap or hand sanitizer, and follow all other hygiene standards as issued by the Controller.  b. Venues or parts of venues that provide gambling activities and services may open if they ensure strict adherence to the COVID-19 safety guidelines issued by the Controller in relation to operating a gambling activity and service.  c. No licensed premises shall sell takeaway alcohol on Friday, Saturday, or Sunday, except restaurants that may continue to serve alcohol as regulated by their liquor license.  All schools, educational institutions, markets, and shopping centers are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

All religious activities are exempted from gathering numbers and may continue to operate but must comply with Niupela Pasin. All political rallies,  events, and gatherings only connected to the  National  Election  2022 are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

Nationwide, religious, school, and political gatherings, as well as crowds at markets and shopping malls, are allowed to exceed 100 people from 16 Feb 2022, though the limitation remains for public gatherings.  Gatherings are still banned in high-risk regions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46

An immediate ban is placed on gatherings of over 100 people in Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

The government limits capacity on public transport services. Police have threatened to impound any vehicle that violates capacity limits, though compliance and enforcement vary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46

As of Feb 16, restrictions on public transport have been lifted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46
There is no curfew in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Fully vaccinated citizens, permanent residents, and foreign nationals can enter the country with written approval from the National Pandemic Controller's Office; tourist travel remains banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Papua New Guinea authorities have reopened borders to tourists as of Feb. 16. Officials have also lifted requirements for arrivals to have written permission from the National Pandemic Controller's Office to enter. All arrivals must be fully vaccinated, though Papua New Guinea citizens and travelers under 18 years old are exempted. Entrants must also provide a negative COVID-19 test obtained within 72 hours before departure and undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival. Individuals who tested positive in the last three months must provide a medical certificate indicating the person is no longer infectious. Authorities are not enforcing mandatory quarantine for most arrivals; people who test positive when tested on arrival must quarantine for seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/

All travelers age 5 and over must present a negative COVID-19 PCR or Abbot Panbio Antigen Rapid Diagnostic test administered no earlier than 72 hours prior to departure from their original point of origin.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103200822/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P

PNG government announced a K5.6 billion economic stimulus package, including a K600 million credit line to support businesses and individuals, in coordination with the banks and financial institutions, and K500 million in support from superannuation savings to employees affected by the economic slowdown.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103200822/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P

The Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG) reduced the Kina Facility Rate (KFR) â the main policy rate - by 200 basis points to 3 percent from 5 percent and asked the commercial banks to reduce their respective Indicative Lending Rates. BPNG also reduced the Cash Reserve Requirement to 7 percent from 10 percent to provide additional liquidity to the commercial banks. All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There are Covid-19 awareness videos and posters updated online at the specialized Covid-19 website.    https://archive.ph/AnJ2Q

Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain free or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital, the Taurama Aquatic Center, and other public clinics in Port Moresby. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained at provincial hospitals and other health facilities.     Non-symptomatic persons and persons wanting expedited results may obtain services through private medical facilities, including:        2K Medical Clinic      Pacific International Hospital      ASPEN Medical      Sky Health Medical Services      International SOS    Testing conducted through private medical facilities may cost as much as 250 USD.    Though electronic test results from such facilities are generally available within 24-72 hours upon request    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221200426/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
COVID-19 testing services and health care capacity in the country are limited only to symptomatic people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Contact tracing is being done but is limited    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221003018/https:/www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220215-papua-new-guinea-to-reopen-borders-shut-by-covid
COVID-19 testing services and health care capacity including contact tracing in the country are limited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

People 12 years old or above must wear facemasks in public places, except childcare centers and banks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221003018/https:/www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220215-papua-new-guinea-to-reopen-borders-shut-by-covid

All people must wear masks in the entire country whenever going outside.  The following persons are exempted from these Measures:  a. Children under 12;  b. Persons with underlying medical conditions which inhibit their ability to wear a Mask or Face Covering, including persons with physical or mental illness or impairment, or disability  c. Persons who are unable to place or remove a Mask or Face Covering without assistance;  d. Persons undergoing dental treatment or other medical care to the extent that the procedure requires that no face covering may be worn;  e. Persons within an area of work designated for them and not for public access, and who can work in an environment whereby they are a minimum of 2 meters from any other person;  f. Persons participating in sporting activities;  g. When directed to remove the face covering to ascertain identity; and  h. During emergencies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312171122/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%209-Mandatory%20Mask%20Wearing-16.02.22.pdf

Vaccines are available for anyone above age 18.    Vaccines being given include Astra Zeneca, Johnson and Johnson and Sinopharm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207071311/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/situation-reports-2/

All persons 18 years of age or older are eligible for vaccination in Papua New Guinea. AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, and Sinopharm are available in Papua New Guinea.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Booster doses of vaccine have been prioritized for the elderly    https://archive.vn/WhNra
Boosters are available for eligible individuals like elderly people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccines are available for anyone over the age of 18    On Jan 17th, booster doses were approved for those with underlying health conditions, immunocompromised and the elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031023630/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/    https://archive.vn/WhNra
All persons 18 years of age or older are eligible for vaccination in Papua New Guinea.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

348, 938 people who are older than 18 years old are actively vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312172640/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/

The national vaccine programme has been extended to children between 5-11 years old, but no vaccine differentiated measures are in place for this age group.  _______________________    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128143718/https://www.moe.gov.sg/search?q=%2A&app=site_search&fq=content_type_s%3A%28%22news%22%29&sort=modified_dt+desc  _______________________    Quote (2):  "The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) will be working with the Ministry of Health (MOH) to extend the national vaccination programme to cover over 300,000 children aged 5 to 11, starting with the older children from 27 December 2021. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128144057/https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/20211221-protecting-our-children-from-covid-19-with-vaccination-for-5-to-11-year-olds  ______________________    Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE: There are presently no plans to introduce vaccination-differentiated safe management measures for children aged 12 years and below, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Tuesday (Dec 14)." no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread." No Coding changes for the period of 08 -11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.  A grace period for partially vaccinated individuals is in place until 31 January 2022.    50% of employees are now allowed back to the workplaces at any given point in time; although, they must adhere to the vaccine mandate as afore mentioned.  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings  ___________    Quote (2):  "The following measures are put in place to slow the rate of transmission and minimise strain on our healthcare capacity.  From 1 January 2022, more employees3 are allowed to return to the workplace.  Up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home can be at the workplace at any point in time. For example, a company with 100 employees who can work from home can have up to 50 of these employees at the workplace at any point in time."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220103082447/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/requirements-for-safe-management-measures

no coding changes for the period of 27 Feb - 07 Mar 2022.    Easing and streamlining of current covid measures to be delayed further as cases remain high.    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: The streamlining of COVID-19 safe management measures will be postponed again as daily local case numbers have remained high.  "The number of cases currently hospitalised also remains high, and our healthcare workers are still under significant pressure," said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Friday (Mar 4)."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220307093838/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-streamlining-safe-management-measures-delay-moh-high-case-numbers-2539831  _______________________  *** Please refer to notes dated 26 Feb 2022:    no coding changes for the period of 23-26 Feb 2022.  ____________________  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:  no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

no coding changes for the period of 08-12 March 2022.    Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111938/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapore-to-simplify-covid-19-rules-from-march-15-including-allowing-five-household-visitors-at-a-time  __________________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 07 March 2022:    no coding changes for the period of 27 Feb - 07 Mar 2022. No Coding changes for the period of 08 - 11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Vaccine differentiated measures are currently in place with only vaccinated individuals allowed into events. Current Covid safety measurements still prevail in all settings.  _________________    Quote (1):  " From 1 January 2022, the concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed. Only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented."    "ATTRACTIONS,SHOWS & CRUISES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated.    CONGREGATIONAL & WORSHIP SERVICES  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 worshippers.  Vaccinated performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.    MARRIAGE SOLEMNISATIONS  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 attendees.    MUSEUMS & PUBLIC LIBRARIES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128150314/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  __________________    Quote (2):  "(D) Expanding VDS to More Venues    10. Vaccination is key to protecting our population even as SMMs are further relaxed. From 1 December 2021, we will expand VDS to more settings and activities, including in all Libraries under the National Library Board (NLB), and selected activities in community clubs/centres under Peopleâs Association (PA). By restricting entry to only individuals who have been fully vaccinated, we can further reduce the risk of transmission in such settings.     11. A summary of the updated community measures from 22 November 2021 can be found in Annex A.     (E) Removal of VDS Concession for Voluntarily Unvaccinated Individuals     12. We will further strengthen efforts to protect unvaccinated individuals from getting infected, as they are subject to greater risks of severe illness. Under current rules, unvaccinated individuals can get a PET and show a negative test result to enter a VDS setting. We will remove this concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated.  Hence, only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event-specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented. We will effect this on 1 January 2022, to allow time for more individuals to complete their primary series vaccination regime. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220116160914/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-our-transition-towards-covid-resilience

no coding changes for the period of 12-22 February 2022.  Although there have been some adjustments to covid measures, there are still some specific restrictions depending on the type and capacity of the event.  ____________    Quote (1):    "Capacity Limits    From 4 March 2022, specific event size limits for events such as religious services, business events, media conferences, funerary memorial events, wedding receptions, and mask-on classes1, will be lifted. Zoning requirements will also be removed.    However, for large events and settings which pose more infection risks, capacity limits will be imposed as a precaution. These will include attractions, cruises, MICE and large work-related events, as well as large performing arts venues or sports stadiums. For other settings such as shopping malls and large standalone stores, the current density limit of 10sqm/pax roughly translates to 50% capacity too. For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

Ridership rates have been on the rise and more hopes that might return to pre-pandemic levels. not restrictions in services seen.  ____________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Public transport ridership recovered in 2021 on the back of relaxed Covid-19 restrictions, but the numbers are still the second lowest since 2010.  Bus and train rides averaged 5.259 million a day in 2021 - 4.3 per cent higher than in 2020, based on figures released by the Land Transport Authority on Monday (Feb 21)."    "More people are expected to return to taking public transport as the economy reopens further this year.  Last month, bus and rail rides averaged 5.785 million a day - a 10 per cent jump from the 2021 average.  But observers reckon that it would take some time to go back to the all-time ridership high of 7.691 million seen before the Covid-19 pandemic in 2019." Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling. No Coding changes for the period of 08 -11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Vaccine differentiated measures for travelers to Singapore have been in place for many months and have recently increased to include a mandate for work passes. There are a few exceptions but these might require pre-approval but a government body.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "Persons who are medically unfit to be vaccinated are not allowed to travel under the VTL (Air).  Unvaccinated short-term visitors will not be allowed to travel to Singapore.    However, unvaccinated:  Singapore Citizens  Permanent Residents, and  Long-Term Pass holders who have received entry approval via the SC/PR Familial Ties Lane  may still travel to Singapore on a non-designated flight. They will be subject to the prevailing Stay-Home Notice (SHN) and COVID-19 test requirements upon entry into Singapore.    3. What must travellers present as their proof of vaccination at check-in and arrival immigration?  I am a...	My proof of vaccination was issued...	I will need to present...  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	In Singapore	Either a valid vaccination status on the TraceTogether or HealthHub app or a vaccination certificate issued by the Singapore Ministry of Health.  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	Overseas	One of the accepted proof of vaccination, which may include your overseas-issued vaccination certificate  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	In Singapore	A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*. Please click here for more details.  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	Overseas	  A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*, and an accepted proof of vaccination, if necessary.    *On the VTP (Air) application portal, please select one of the following options depending on your pass type:  MOM Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a holder of an Employment Pass, Work Pass, Dependentâs Pass, MOM Long-Term Visit Pass, etc.; or  MOE Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a Student Pass holder."    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152708/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/vtl/faq  _____________________    Quote (2):  "Covid Vaccination Mandatory In Singapore From February 2022  Singapore: Singapore has made Covid vaccination a mandatory condition for the approval of new applications for work passes, long-term passes and permanent residence in Singapore from February 1 next year. Those renewing their work passes will also have to be vaccinated, The Straits Times reported, citing the multi-ministry task force (MMTF) on Covid."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128152404/https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/coronavirus-covid-vaccination-mandatory-in-singapore-from-february-2022-2673179  ____________________    Quote (3):  "Calibrating Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) Testing Regimes    24.    On 31 December 2021, we announced a four-week extension to the enhanced 7- day testing regime for travellers arriving via VTLs in order to facilitate the detection of imported Omicron cases and slow transmission into the community. This has bought time for us to booster vaccinate more residents, learn more about the Omicron variant and make necessary adjustments to our COVID-19 strategy. As imported cases now form a shrinking proportion of our overall cases, we will simplify the VTL testing regime.    25.     These measures are less relevant now. Hence, VTL travellers entering Singapore after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours via both air and land checkpoints will only be required to do unsupervised self-administered ARTs from Day 2 to Day 7 of their arrivals if they need to leave their place of residence or accommodation. Travellers need not submit their ART results but must test negative before going out. VTL travellers who arrive before 23 January 2022, 2359 hours are still required to continue with the existing testing regime (i.e. unsupervised self-administered ART on Days 2, 4, 5 and 6 with submission of results online, and supervised ART on Days 3 and 7 from their arrival).    26.    Travellers who test positive on ARTs (i.e. the on-arrival test for VTL-Land and unsupervised self-administered ARTs on Days 2 to 7) no longer need to undergo a confirmatory PCR test, but should instead simply recover under Protocol 2.2 That said, those who identify themselves as potentially at risk (as stipulated in Annex C) should visit a doctor for medical advice after testing positive even if they feel well.    27.     We will continue to maintain a 50% limit on VTL flight and bus tickets for entry into Singapore for now. We will continue to review the local and global COVID-19 situation and adjust our measures accordingly.    Facilitating Travel for Recently-Recovered Travellers    28.    With the growing number of cases worldwide, there is a rise in the number of travellers who have recently recovered from COVID-19. Such travellers can continue to shed non-infectious viral fragments even after they have recovered, and therefore test positive for COVID-19 despite posing no infection risk. As fully vaccinated individuals who recently recovered from infection have a high level of immunity through their recent COVID-19 infection and vaccination, the likelihood of reinfection is low.    29.     Hence, travellers arriving after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours who are fully vaccinated and recently recovered (i.e. within 90 days of their last infection) will be exempted from all testing and SHN requirements if they are able to provide appropriate documentary proof. Non-fully vaccinated recently-recovered travellers will be exempted from pre-departure testing requirements, but will still be subjected to all other prevailing border measures. This will facilitate the safe return of recently-recovered residents who travel overseas. See Annex D for the list of documentation to be presented by such travellers at check-in and arrival immigration to qualify for this exemption."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152933/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/focusing-our-resources-and-refining-our-healthcare-protocols-to-deal-with-the-omicron-wave

Only Vaccinated individuals are allowed to travel to Singapore via designated Vaccinated Travel Lanes. Travel restrictions for these individuals  have been recently amended such that quarantine and PCR testing has been lifted with only ARTs required (Antigen Rapid tests). no coding changes for the period of 08-12 March 2022.    Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111938/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapore-to-simplify-covid-19-rules-from-march-15-including-allowing-five-household-visitors-at-a-time    --------------------------=  Quote (3):  "Updates to Border Measures  27.          We had earlier simplified our country/region classification and border measures on 22 February 2022 to pave the way for more Vaccinated Travel. Over the past weeks, imported infection numbers have stayed very low â around 1% of total daily infections â because many countries have already passed the peak of their Omicron infection waves.  28.          Given the above, we will now further rationalise our travel protocols by switching to an unsupervised self-swab Antigen Rapid Test (ART) within 24 hours of entry for General Category (Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL)) and Category I travellers entering Singapore from 14 March 2022, 2359 hours. This will replace the previous requirement for a supervised self-swab ART. Travellers are required to report their unsupervised self-swab ART test result via sync.gov.sg3 before proceeding with their activities in Singapore. Border measures for travellers arriving from 14 March 2022, 2359h can be found at Annex C."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.03.12-113148/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-our-transition-to-resilience  __________________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 07 March 2022:    no coding changes for the period of 27 Feb - 07 Mar 2022. In additon, the government announced SGD$130 million (Approx USD$ 95 million) stimuli in the form of cash vouchers that can be utilized at select merchants across the country,    ___________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All Singaporean households can now collect $100 worth of vouchers that they can spend at about 10,000 participating hawkers and heartland merchants.    The community development council (CDC) vouchers, worth $130 million in total and given out to 1.3 million households, are available for collection digitally from Monday (Dec 13) and can be used till Dec 31, 2022."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213094222/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/100-worth-of-cdc-vouchers-for-each-sporean-household-available-for-collection-online  ________________    Quote (2): [Exchange Rate]  "Dec 13, 2021 09:38 UTC  Singapore Dollar	130,000,000.00 SGD	  US Dollar	95035922.924214	@ 1.367904"    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20211213094242/https://www.x-rates.com/historical/?from=SGD&amount=130000000&date=2021-12-13  ______________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021.     ____________________________________  ****Please refer to previous notes dated 6 Nov 2021:    no coding changes to the period of 02-06 Nov 2021.   ___________________  ***Please refer to notes dates 01 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 24 Oct -01 Nov.  ___________________  *** Please refer to notes dates 23 Oct 2021    Support to continue until Nov 21 in light of the further extensions of the current restrictions.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: A S$640 million support package will be rolled out for affected businesses and workers, after it was announced on Wednesday (Oct 20) that Singapore will extend its COVID-19 restrictions by nearly a month.  The stabilisation phase, which started on Sep 27 to help reduce the strain on the healthcare system, was scheduled to last until Oct 24.   It has now been extended until Nov 21, with a review of the measures at the two-week mark. They may be adjusted based on the situation then, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a media release.  During the stabilisation phase, social gatherings and dining-in have been capped at groups of two, while work-from-home has been the default arrangement.  Given the extended restrictions, the Government will continue with the Jobs Support Scheme until Nov 21, at 25 per cent wage support for sectors significantly affected by the tightened measures.  These include F&B, retail, cinemas, museums and art galleries, family entertainment, tourism, gyms and fitness studios, as well as performing arts and arts education.  A two-week rental waiver will be given to qualifying tenants on government-owned commercial properties.  Eligible tenant-occupiers and owner-occupiers of privately-owned commercial properties will also be given a 0.5-month rental relief cash payout under the Rental Support Scheme (RSS).  Cooked food and market stallholders in centres managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) or operators appointed by NEA will receive a 0.5-month rental waiver.    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211023041636/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-support-package-jobs-support-scheme-extended-restrictions-2257036

No coding changes for the period of 12-22 Feb 2022.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "About Combined Test Centres (CTCs)  Combined Test Centres (CTCs), previously known as Regional Screening Centres (RSCs), are set up around Singapore to carry out COVID-19 swab tests for target groups from the general community who are well or have been diagnosed with acute respiratory infection. CTCs provide both the self-paid Antigen Rapid Test (ART) and the COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) swab test.    Click here for the locations of CTCs.  About Quick Test Centres (QTCs)  Quick Test Centres (QTCs) provide self-paid ART, where the test will be self-administered and supervised by an approved COVID-19 test provider. The test will cost $15 (inclusive of GST), with payment to be made at the QTCs through cashless modes, such as Mastercard, NETS, PayNow and Visa. Individuals will need to bring along their photo identification for verification at the QTC.    Both the CTCs and QTCs are important as they support COVID-19 testing, which helps to keep our homes and communities safe, especially as we re-open and resume our activities.    Click here for the locations of QTCs CTCs."    "Expanded Venues for COVID-19 Testing for Symptomatic Individuals  Members of the public who are experiencing acute respiratory symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, flu or runny nose), and are unable to secure an appointment at any of the Swab and Send Home (SASH) clinics during the weekend and public holidays, may book an appointment here, at one of our Combined Testing Centres (CTCs) to get a government-funded ART and confirmatory PCR test.    For the locations of CTCs, click here.  Self-Paid Antigen Rapid Test for Pre-Event Testing  From 1 October 2021, individuals aged 3 years and above, who need a valid negative COVID-19 ART result for entry into venues that require a negative Pre-Event or Pre-Visit Test may book an appointment at any of the QTCs for a self-paid ART. Minors aged 3 to 12, must be accompanied by a caregiver, aged 21 years old and above. The caregiver may be required to help administer the test if the minor is unable to do so. The results, which are valid for 24 hours, may be used to meet requirements such as those for pre-event test or pre-visit test.     Individuals are required to book an appointment at any of the following testing venues, prior to the visit."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222052846/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/quick-test-centres-%28qtcs%29

No Coding changes for the period of 08 - 11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    no coding changes to the period of 18-28 January 2022.  ____________  ***Please refer to previous notes dates 17 January 2022.    No coding changes for the period of 07-17 January 2022.  All restrictions will remain the same all the way to and during the Chinese New Year (CNY) period in Early to mid February 2022.    Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030005/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030048/https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/no-plans-relax-covid-19-curbs-chinese-new-year-holidays-lawrence-wong-1784181  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030109/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/we-dont-intend-to-relax-further-says-lawrence-wong-as-covid-curbs-look-set-to  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030130/https://www.gov.sg/article/safe-management-measures-and-chinese-new-year  ____________________  *** Please refer to previous notes:    No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 14-18 Dec 2021. _  __________   ***Please refer to notes dated 13 Dec 2021:  Face masks continue to be mandated any time outside of the home. _    ______________    Quote (1): ""How does COVID-19 spread? Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.  Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.  To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible.""      Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211206075819/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

No coding changes for the period of 12-22 Feb 2022.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "It is mandatory for all persons who are 6 years old and above to wear a mask when leaving their homes. Masks help to reduce the expulsion and transmission of droplets, which is the predominant route of transmission of COVID-19. It is therefore important for you to wear a mask, so that you will not spread the infection to others if you are infected. This is important even if you feel well, because you may be infected but asymptomatic."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222052244/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general/faqs---masks-and-personal-protective-equipment-%28ppe%29

Universal availability for the initial regimen with booster shots allowed for prioritized groups [Link (2)]. The current validity duration of the initial vaccine regimen is under review - in order for individuals to maintain a ""fully vaccinated"" status, they may be required to take booster shots or to have a second regimen in a year's time [Link (3)]. Children under 12 are currently under review to possibly receive the vaccine in the future [Link (4)].  The government has recently announced that children from 5-11 years old are not able to take part in the national vaccination program. It campaign has not yet begun but is schedule to by the end of 2021. [Link (5)] .  Additionally, vaccines for children aged 5-11 years old are now eligible for the covid vaccine under the National Vaccination Programme. [Link (6)]    Groups: Universal availability    Vaccines:    1. Moderna (Government Funded)   2. Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty (Government Funded)   3. Sinovac-Coronavac (Government Funded) [7] - 3 doses required for Full Vax status [8]  4. Sinopharm (Government Funded/Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR    5. AstraZeneca (Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR      *SAR = Special Access Route  ____________________________________      Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211116203225/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination   Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20211014035410/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-seniors-immunocompromised-elderly-care-homes-2154791   Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20211112144700/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid19-vaccine-expiry-date-365-days-booster-moh-2308821   Link (4): http://web.archive.org/web/20211119083158/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/kkh-recruiting-children-aged-5-to-11-for-covid-19-vaccination-trial   Link (5): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213092117/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/moh-covid-19-vaccination-children-singapore-2372631  Link (6): http://web.archive.org/web/20220102123050/https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/20211221-protecting-our-children-from-covid-19-with-vaccination-for-5-to-11-year-olds  Link (7): http://web.archive.org/web/20220207085503/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination  Link (8): http://web.archive.org/web/20220207085505/https://www.vaccine.gov.sg/health-advisory/

No Coding changes for the period of 08 - 11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Regardless of vaccination status, there are strict rules for each group of individuals before being able to enter nursing homes and hospitals to visit the elderly.    From the 24 of January, all in-persons will be suspended for 4 weeks until 20 February 2022 in light of the current omicron wave in Singapore.  _________________    Quote (1):  "[Updated 21 January 2022]    To better protect our patients and healthcare workers, particularly in settings with vulnerable persons, in-person visits to all hospital wards1 and residential care homes will be suspended for a period of four weeks, from 24 January to 20 February 2022 (both dates inclusive).    During this period, hospitals and homes can make assessments on a case-by-case basis to allow in-person visits for exceptional cases. More details for visits to hospitals and homes can be found below.    Pre-visit testing requirements at hospitals and homes    Visitors who are allowed into hospital wards and homes will be required to show a valid negative ART result obtained within the last 24 hours of each visit. All tests are to be self-funded by the visitor. This is a mandatory requirement for all visitors regardless of vaccination status, except for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and are able to present a valid Pre-Event Test (PET) exemption notice2.   Fully vaccinated or medically ineligible visitors can perform an unsupervised self-administered ART or opt for an ART administered by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including tests performed at Quick Test Centres) to fulfil the pre-visit testing requirement. Those who opt to undergo unsupervised self-administered ART will be required to show evidence of a valid ART result, e.g. present a time-stamped photo of the dated ART result and photo ID for verification prior to entry.  Non-fully vaccinated visitors would be required to show results of ART administered or supervised by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including Quick Test Centres). Results from unsupervised self-administered ART will not be accepted for this group of visitors.    In-person visits at hospitals  The following patient groups will continue to be allowed visitors on a case-by case basis, as assessed by the hospitals:   a. Patients who are in critical condition;    b. Paediatric patients;   c. Birthing/post-partum mothers; and    d. Patients requiring additional care support from caregivers. Examples of caregivers include those providing assistance to inpatients who have mental incapacities or family members who are undergoing caregiver training to better  care for their loved ones after hospital discharge.      The above patient groups would be allowed only one pre-designated visitor, with one visit per day. Patients who are in critical condition may be allowed up to five pre-designated visitors, with a maximum of two visitors at the patientâs bedside at any one time.  All visitors approved to enter hospital wards must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or use the patientsâ toilets in the wards. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ beds.    1Includes public acute hospitals, community hospitals and private hospitals   2 Recovered individuals (within last 180 days) can obtain a PET Exemption Notice from any clinic  offering ART or Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing services."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128155429/https://www.gov.sg/article/resuming-in-person-visits-to-hospitals-and-residential-care-homes  _______________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - In-person visits to hospital wards and residential care homes will be suspended for the next four weeks amid a surge in Omicron Covid-19 cases over the past few weeks.  This is to protect Singapore's healthcare capacity and vulnerable seniors, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Friday (Jan 21). The suspension will last from next Monday (Jan 24) to Feb 20."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220122211503/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/visits-to-hospital-wards-nursing-homes-suspended-for-4-weeks-amid-covid-19-omicron-surge

No Coding changes for the period of 08 - 11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.    ***unable to tick "mandatory vaccination" as there is no suitable category for workers in general***  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. As of January 19, all inter-island travel has been suspended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228041738/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Pattaya City Public Relations announced on 25th February 2022 that people shouldnât hold gatherings or parties with more than 50 people.  Pattaya postponed a music festival. They are still considering whether or not to cancel water fights and parties on Songkran.    https://archive.ph/hjchB

Localities remain grouped into orange, yellow, and blue zones in decreasing order of strictness. The government categorizes Bangkok and eight provinces as blue zones and 44 other provinces as the stricter orange zones. The following designations are in effect as of Feb. 23:    Blue: Bangkok; Chonburi, Kanchanaburi, Krabi, Nonthaburi, Pathum Thani, Phang Nga, and Phuket provinces    Yellow: Ang Thong, Bueng Kan, Chai Nat, Chaiyaphum, Kamphaeng Phet, Lampang, Lamphun, Loei, Nakhon Phanom, Nakhon Sawan, Narathiwat, Nong Bua Lam Phu, Nong Khai, Pattani, Phetchabun, Phichit, Phitsanulok, Phrae, Sakon Nakhon, Sing Buri, Sukhothai, Suphan Buri, Uthai Thani, Uttaradit, and Yala provinces    Orange: All other provinces    Gatherings are capped at 500 people in orange zones, and 1,000 people in yellow and blue zones.     https://archive.ph/p5He8

The governmentâs Center for COVID-19 Situation Administration said that starting from March 1, vaccinated international travelers will still have to undergo one reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test after arriving. But they will no longer have to take another RT-PCR test on the fifth day of their arrival; instead they will able to do a rapid antigen test and report the result on a cellphone app.  Travelers who are not fully vaccinated must quarantine for 10 days and take three PCR tests.     https://archive.ph/Y8oFY

No policy update.  On 24th January, the 4th phase of âKhon La Khreungâ, the Thai governmentâs co-payment subsidy scheme was approved. Through this scheme, the government co-pays 50% of certain living costs (food, drink and other goods and services), capped at a maximum of 150 baht/day. Phase 3 had expired on 31st December 2021, and Phase 4 will come into effect from 1st February 2022 to 30th April 2022.    https://archive.ph/PvCJf

On 18 Feb 2022, the Tonga Prime Minister announced that all schools will remain closed for a week until 28 Feb 2022.     Government of the Kingdom of Tonga:  https://archive.ph/2q2Gg

On 25 Feb 2022, the Tonga Prime Minister has announced easing some of the COVID-19 restrictions including a new night curfew and tertiary education to start next week.  Tertiary education will begin as well next week.  Hon. Huâakavameiliku made the announcement during a Press Conference with the media today.  The PM says TVET (Tonga Technical and Vocational Education), TIST (Tonga Institute of Science & Technology), TIHE (Tonga Institute among tertiary institution) are among other tertiary institutions that will start next week.    Parliament of Tonga:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301231213/https://www.parliament.gov.to/media-centre/latest-news/latest-news-in-english/889-tertiary-students-return-to-school-easy-restriction-next-week-despite-rise-in-covid-19-positive-cases

On 18 Feb 2022, the Tonga Prime Minister announced that from 21 Feb 2022, businesses can start to open after receiving prior approvals from the Ministry of Health. Liquor licensed tradings remain closed.     Government of the Kingdom of Tonga:  https://archive.ph/2q2Gg  https://archive.ph/VH6g1

Hon. Huâakavameiliku confirmed that all businesses who have been approved to open will need to follow their compliance plans with effect from 28 Feb 2022.  This includes retail shops, fast-food takeaways, hardware and wholesalers plus media outlets who are currently operating.  Construction, commercial and domestic fisheries plus farmers can also resume as long as they follow Health and COVID-19 protocol.  All liquor licensed trading remain closed.    Government of the Kingdom of Tonga:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225093448/https://www.gov.to/press-release/prime-minister-confirms-new-curfew-hours-as-tertiary-students-return-to-school/

On 25 Aug 2021, Tonga legislative assembly approved the Public Health Amendment Bill 2021.  The Bill introduces a new 181A section intends to make vaccinations compulsory ONLY when prior declarations of public health emergency as well as an emergency notifiable condition in place. This includes the COVID-19 vaccine.    RNZ News:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130014/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/455273/in-brief-news-from-around-the-pacific    Parliament of Tonga:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215100013/https://www.parliament.gov.to/media-centre/latest-news/latest-news-in-english/840-parliament-passes-the-public-health-amendment-bill-2021

Key measures of the covid relief package 4.0:  Accelerating relief for individuals: In addition to administering aid in accordance with last year's standards, a subsidy is available for families with students enrolled in elementary school and below, as well as disabled students in junior and senior high school and the first three years of five-year junior colleges. Living allowances are also going out to children, young people, the elderly and the disabled in low to middle-low income households. Excluding those above a certain income, agricultural and fisheries workers, the self-employed, and workers without fixed employers also receive living allowances.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055359/https://english.ey.gov.tw/News3/9E5540D592A5FECD/10e57174-8e16-4710-b4ac-9882bd8db7de

Financial Relief    Three Ways to Help from Public Banks    1. Policy Lending Package: Support SMEs funding to operate business.    2. Loan Extension: Companies or individuals can apply to defer principal repayment or extend loan.    3. Credit card payment deferral: Individuals can apply to defer card payment without penalty and interest.    The measures of reducing interest rate from public banks    Residential Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30  Consuming Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30 (including credit card, unsecured loan, car loan)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055846/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/taiwan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
Dedicated websites amongst them Taiwan Centre for Disease Control.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226055653/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En

(4) Foreign nationals, mainland Chinese, or Hong Kong and Macao residents who will depart from Taiwan.    (5) Family members of people traveling abroad for the reasons listed above.    (6) Approved by the Central Epidemic Command Center.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226055641/https://www6.vghtpe.gov.tw/reg/ctestAnn.do?lang=EN

COVID-19 vaccine appointments for the first shot, second shot, or booster shot are widely available to people aged 12 or older.    Eligibility: individuals who registered on the System before 6 a.m. on December 13 and meet any of the following criteria:  1. The first dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 12 or older (born on December 16, 2009, or earlier).  2. The second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 31, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of BNT before November 18 (inclusive).  3. Mixing of AZ with a second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 16, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of AZ before October 21 (inclusive).    Remarks: The 23rd phase of the publicly funded vaccine platform has been opened since 16 Feb 2022    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062114/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kaT7wZ1ubFZzyHlWUQsENg?typeid=158  https://web.archive.org/web/20220226060301/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=Z0Az4TD0aBC1AsNJBlqSlA

The majority of people with clinical symptoms and without travel history or contact with a COVID-19 case will not be tested.  2. People who have recently arrived to Vanuatu from another country. Testing will be conducted among all people who have recently arrived to Vanuatu (by sea and air). Testing will be done for all people who enter Vanuatu regardless of the country COVID-19 status they came from. People will be tested even if they do not have symptoms.  3. For people exiting Vanuatu Some countries require travelers to provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test prior to entry to their country."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308001034/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/questions-answers
